description: "Neural Networks for Machine Learning" is a comprehensive course taught by Geoffrey Hinton, a pioneer in artificial intelligence and a professor at the University of Toronto. Originally offered on Coursera between 2012 and 2014, the course delves into the fundamentals of artificial neural networks and their applications in machine learning tasks such as speech and object recognition, image segmentation, language modeling, and human motion analysis. It emphasizes both foundational algorithms and practical techniques essential for effectively training deep learning models. Designed for intermediate learners with a solid understanding of calculus and programming experience (particularly in Python), the course combines theoretical insights with practical guidance, making it a valuable resource for those interested in the evolution and application of deep learning technologies.

This beginner-friendly YouTube series breaks down the fundamentals of neural networks using intuitive explanations and clear visuals. Stephen Welch guides viewers through core concepts like forward and backward propagation, gradient descent, and matrix operations, making it ideal for those new to machine learning.

Delivered by DeepMind researcher Nando de Freitas, this comprehensive lecture series covers a wide range of deep learning topics, including convolutional and recurrent neural networks, variational autoencoders, and reinforcement learning. The course balances theoretical insights with practical examples, catering to both beginners and advanced learners.

This graduate-level course focuses on deep learning techniques for perception tasks such as image classification and object detection. Dhruv Batra delves into convolutional neural networks, backpropagation, and optimization methods, providing students with a solid foundation in applying deep learning to visual data.

Ali Ghodsi's course offers a statistical perspective on deep learning, covering topics like neural network architectures, training algorithms, and regularization techniques. The lectures are designed to provide a deep understanding of the mathematical principles underpinning deep learning models.

This renowned course explores the application of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to visual recognition tasks. Andrej Karpathy and colleagues cover topics such as image classification, object detection, and neural network optimization, making it a staple for those interested in computer vision.

Richard Socher's course delves into deep learning methods for natural language processing (NLP), including word embeddings, recurrent neural networks, and sequence-to-sequence models. The lectures provide both theoretical background and practical insights into applying deep learning to language tasks.

This lecture series features talks from leading researchers in the field of deep learning, covering cutting-edge topics and advancements. The diverse range of speakers provides insights into various applications and research directions within deep learning.

An updated version of the 2015 course, this iteration includes new content and refinements based on the latest developments in CNNs and visual recognition. The course continues to be a comprehensive resource for understanding deep learning in computer vision.

Hugo Larochelle's course provides a thorough introduction to neural networks, covering supervised, unsupervised, and semi-supervised learning. The lectures emphasize both the theoretical foundations and practical implementations of neural network models.

An evolution of CS224d, this course focuses on modern NLP techniques using deep learning, including attention mechanisms and transformer models. The curriculum reflects the rapid advancements in NLP, providing students with up-to-date knowledge and skills.

This course offers a comprehensive introduction to deep learning for computer vision, focusing on convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Topics include image classification, object detection, and neural network architectures, providing both theoretical foundations and practical applications in visual recognition tasks.

An advanced graduate-level course covering cutting-edge research in deep learning. It delves into topics like generative models, unsupervised learning, and deep reinforcement learning, emphasizing both theoretical understanding and practical implementation.

Designed for beginners, this crash course introduces the fundamentals of deep learning, including neural networks, backpropagation, and popular architectures like CNNs and RNNs. It balances theoretical concepts with hands-on coding exercises.

This course explores deep learning techniques and their applications across various domains. It covers topics such as neural network architectures, training methodologies, and real-world applications in areas like image and speech processing.

A comprehensive course that covers the foundations of deep learning, including neural networks, optimization algorithms, and practical strategies for building deep learning systems. It emphasizes real-world applications and best practices in model development.

This course provides an in-depth look at deep learning methodologies, focusing on both theoretical aspects and practical implementations. Topics include neural network architectures, training techniques, and applications in computer vision and natural language processing.

course: Advanced Deep Learning and Reinforcement Learning
description: A lecture series that delves into advanced topics in deep learning and reinforcement learning. It covers state-of-the-art research, including deep Q-networks, policy gradients, and applications in complex environments.

An introductory course in machine learning, covering fundamental concepts such as supervised and unsupervised learning, model evaluation, and algorithmic approaches. It lays the groundwork for understanding and applying machine learning techniques.

This course offers a rigorous introduction to deep learning, focusing on mathematical foundations, neural network architectures, and training algorithms. It emphasizes a deep understanding of the principles underlying deep learning models.

professor: Alexander Amini, Harini Suresh and others, MIT
description: A fast-paced introduction to deep learning, covering key concepts such as neural networks, backpropagation, and applications in areas like computer vision and natural language processing. The course includes hands-on labs and projects.

This course focuses on the application of deep learning techniques to autonomous driving. Topics include perception, control, and decision-making systems, with an emphasis on real-world implementation and challenges in self-driving car technology.

professor: Bhiksha Raj and many others, CMU
description: An introductory course that covers the basics of deep learning, including neural network architectures, training algorithms, and applications. It provides a foundation for understanding and developing deep learning models.

A series of courses that delve into deep learning topics such as neural networks, CNNs, sequence models, and strategies for improving model performance. It combines theoretical insights with practical assignments to build deep learning expertise.

This course offers an in-depth exploration of deep learning, covering topics like neural network design, optimization techniques, and applications in various domains. It balances theoretical concepts with practical implementation.

An advanced course that covers deep learning architectures, training methodologies, and applications. It emphasizes understanding the mathematical foundations and practical aspects of building deep learning models.

This course series focuses on the application of deep learning techniques in artificial intelligence. It covers neural network architectures, training strategies, and real-world applications across various AI domains.

professor: Alex Bronstein and Avi Mendelson, Technion
description: An advanced course that delves into deep learning theories, architectures, and applications. It emphasizes both the mathematical underpinnings and practical considerations in developing deep learning systems.

This course, led by Lex Fridman and other MIT researchers, offers a comprehensive introduction to deep learning. It covers foundational topics such as neural networks, convolutional and recurrent architectures, and extends to advanced subjects like reinforcement learning and generative adversarial networks (GANs). The course emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical implementation, providing students with hands-on experience through projects and assignments. It's designed for individuals seeking to grasp the core concepts and applications of deep learning in various domains.

This video series serves as a companion to the seminal textbook "Deep Learning" by Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio, and Aaron Courville. The lectures delve into the theoretical underpinnings of deep learning, covering topics like linear algebra, probability theory, optimization, and machine learning fundamentals. It's an invaluable resource for readers of the book who wish to reinforce their understanding through visual and auditory means.

This advanced course explores the theoretical aspects of deep learning, aiming to understand why deep neural networks perform so well in practice. It covers topics such as the expressiveness of neural networks, optimization landscapes, generalization, and the interplay between depth and width in architectures. The course is research-oriented, featuring lectures from leading experts in the field

In this visually engaging series, Grant Sanderson demystifies the workings of neural networks using intuitive animations and explanations. The series covers the basics of how neural networks learn, the mathematics behind backpropagation, and how these models can be applied to tasks like digit recognition. It's particularly suited for beginners who prefer a conceptual understanding before diving into code.

CS230 offers a practical approach to deep learning, focusing on building and training neural networks for real-world applications. The course covers a range of topics, including convolutional networks, sequence models, and strategies for improving model performance. Students engage in projects that apply deep learning to areas like computer vision, natural language processing, and healthcare.

The DALI'18 workshop brings together researchers to discuss the theoretical foundations of deep learning. Topics include the mathematical properties of neural networks, optimization challenges, and the statistical mechanics of learning. The workshop aims to bridge the gap between empirical successes and theoretical understanding in deep learning.

This course introduces students to the principles and practices of deep learning. It covers fundamental concepts such as feedforward networks, backpropagation, and regularization techniques. The course also explores applications in areas like computer vision and natural language processing, providing students with hands-on experience through assignments and projects.

Focusing on unsupervised learning techniques, this course delves into methods like autoencoders, generative adversarial networks (GANs), and variational autoencoders (VAEs). It emphasizes the importance of learning from unlabeled data and explores how these methods can be applied to tasks such as image generation and representation learning.

This course provides a broad overview of machine learning, covering both theoretical foundations and practical algorithms. Topics include supervised and unsupervised learning, model evaluation, and the ethical implications of machine learning. It's designed to equip students with the skills needed to apply machine learning techniques across various domains.

professor: Alex Bronstein and Avi Mendelson, Technion
description: This course examines the intersection of deep learning and high-performance computing. It covers how to optimize deep learning models for execution on GPUs and other accelerators, discussing topics like parallel computing, memory management, and efficient algorithm design. The course is ideal for students interested in the computational aspects of deep learning.

professor: Bhiksha Raj and many others, CMU
description: CMU's 11-785 course offers a comprehensive introduction to deep learning, covering topics from basic neural network architectures to advanced models like transformers. The course emphasizes both theoretical understanding and practical implementation, with assignments that involve building models for tasks such as speech recognition and language modeling.

This course provides an in-depth exploration of deep learning techniques and their applications. It covers a range of topics, including convolutional networks, recurrent networks, and generative models. The course also discusses recent advancements in the field and encourages students to engage in research-oriented projects.

This course offers a foundational understanding of deep learning, covering essential topics such as neural network architectures, training algorithms, and regularization techniques. It also explores applications in areas like computer vision and natural language processing, providing students with practical experience through coding assignments.

This course focuses on the practical applications of deep learning across various domains. It covers topics like convolutional and recurrent neural networks, reinforcement learning, and unsupervised learning techniques. Students engage in projects that apply these methods to real-world problems, such as image classification and time-series prediction.

This undergraduate course offers a comprehensive introduction to artificial neural networks, covering both theoretical foundations and practical applications. Students explore various network architectures, including feedforward, convolutional, and recurrent networks, and delve into training algorithms like backpropagation. The course emphasizes hands-on experience, with programming assignments that involve building and training neural networks for tasks such as image recognition and time-series prediction. By the end of the course, students gain a solid understanding of how neural networks function and how they can be applied to solve complex problems.

This graduate-level course provides an in-depth exploration of deep learning techniques, focusing on both theoretical concepts and practical implementations. Topics include optimization methods, regularization techniques, and various neural network architectures such as convolutional and recurrent networks. The course also covers recent advancements in the field, including generative models and unsupervised learning approaches. Through lectures and hands-on assignments, students develop the skills necessary to design, train, and evaluate deep learning models for a variety of applications.

This course introduces students to the fundamentals of deep learning, emphasizing both theoretical understanding and practical skills. The curriculum covers essential topics such as neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. Students engage in hands-on projects that involve implementing and training deep learning models for tasks like natural language processing and computer vision. The course is designed to equip students with the knowledge and experience needed to apply deep learning methods to real-world problems.

This master's level course delves into the theory and practice of deep learning, covering a wide range of topics including feedforward networks, convolutional neural networks, and generative models. Students explore optimization techniques, regularization methods, and the application of deep learning in various domains such as computer vision and natural language processing. The course combines lectures with practical assignments, enabling students to gain hands-on experience in designing and training deep learning models. By the end of the course, students are well-prepared to tackle complex machine learning challenges using deep learning approaches.

professor: Percy Liang and Dorsa Sadigh, Stanford University
description: This foundational course in artificial intelligence covers the core principles and techniques used in the field. Topics include search algorithms, constraint satisfaction problems, probabilistic models, and machine learning methods. Students learn how to formulate problems, design intelligent agents, and apply AI techniques to real-world scenarios. The course combines theoretical lectures with practical assignments, providing a comprehensive understanding of how AI systems are developed and deployed.

This advanced seminar series explores the theoretical underpinnings of deep learning, featuring lectures from leading researchers in the field. Topics include the mathematical foundations of neural networks, optimization landscapes, generalization theory, and the interpretability of deep models. The course encourages critical thinking and in-depth analysis, aiming to bridge the gap between empirical successes and theoretical understanding in deep learning. It's designed for students and researchers interested in the rigorous study of deep learning methodologies.

professor: Debdoot Sheet and Sudeshna Sarkar, IIT-Kgp
description: This course offers a comprehensive overview of deep learning, focusing on both foundational concepts and practical applications. Students study various neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. The course also explores the application of deep learning in areas such as computer vision, natural language processing, and healthcare. Through lectures and hands-on assignments, students gain the skills necessary to develop and deploy deep learning models in real-world scenarios.

course: Designing, Visualizing, and Understanding Deep Neural Networks
description: This course focuses on the design and interpretation of deep neural networks, emphasizing both theoretical insights and practical skills. Students learn about various network architectures, visualization techniques, and methods for understanding model behavior. The curriculum includes topics such as convolutional networks, recurrent networks, and generative models. Through projects and assignments, students develop the ability to design effective deep learning models and gain insights into their inner workings.

professor: Yann LeCun and Alfredo Canziani, NYU
description: Taught by pioneers in the field, this course provides an in-depth exploration of deep learning techniques and their applications. Students study various neural network architectures, including convolutional and recurrent networks, and learn about training methods, optimization algorithms, and regularization techniques. The course also covers advanced topics such as generative models and reinforcement learning. Through lectures and practical assignments, students gain a comprehensive understanding of deep learning and its real-world applications.

This course offers a thorough introduction to deep learning, covering fundamental concepts and practical implementations. Students learn about neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. The course also explores applications in areas such as speech recognition, computer vision, and natural language processing. Through lectures and hands-on assignments, students develop the skills necessary to design, train, and evaluate deep learning models.

This advanced course focuses on unsupervised learning techniques in deep learning, exploring models such as autoencoders, variational autoencoders, and generative adversarial networks. Students study the theoretical foundations of these models and their applications in areas like image generation and representation learning. The course combines lectures with practical assignments, enabling students to implement and experiment with various unsupervised learning approaches.

This course provides a comprehensive introduction to machine learning, covering both theoretical concepts and practical applications. Topics include supervised and unsupervised learning, model evaluation, and algorithm selection. Students engage in hands-on projects that involve implementing machine learning algorithms and applying them to real-world datasets. The course is designed to equip students with the skills necessary to develop and evaluate machine learning models across various domains.

course: Introduction to Deep Learning and Generative Models
description: This course introduces students to deep learning and generative models, covering topics such as neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. Students learn about generative models like variational autoencoders and generative adversarial networks, exploring their theoretical foundations and practical applications. The course includes hands-on assignments that involve implementing and training models for tasks such as image generation and data synthesis.

This course offers a comprehensive overview of deep learning, focusing on both theoretical concepts and practical implementations. Students study various neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. The course also explores applications in areas such as medical imaging and signal processing. Through lectures and hands-on assignments, students gain the skills necessary to develop and deploy deep learning models in real-world scenarios.

professor: Laura Leal-Taixé and Matthias Niessner, TU-München
description: This introductory course provides students with a solid foundation in deep learning, covering essential topics such as neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. Students engage in practical assignments that involve implementing and training models for tasks like image classification and object detection. The course is designed to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary to apply deep learning methods to various applications.

This course offers a comprehensive introduction to deep learning, covering both theoretical foundations and practical applications. Students study various neural network architectures, training algorithms, and optimization techniques. The course also explores applications in areas such as natural language processing and computer vision. Through lectures and hands-on assignments, students develop the skills necessary to design, train, and evaluate deep learning models

professor: Lots of Legends, DeepMind x UCL, London
description: This lecture series features talks from leading researchers in the field of deep learning, covering a wide range of topics including reinforcement learning, generative models, and optimization techniques. The series aims to provide insights into the latest advancements and research directions in deep learning.

professor: Louis-Philippe Morency & others, Carnegie Mellon University
description: This course focuses on building machine learning systems that can process and combine multiple modalities, such as text, audio, and video. Students learn techniques for representation learning, fusion strategies, and multimodal alignment. The course includes recent advances like transformers for multimodal data and challenges like missing modality handling. Practical assignments involve creating models that jointly understand speech, vision, and language, preparing students for real-world applications like human-computer interaction.

This graduate-level course tackles the critical aspects of making AI systems trustworthy, focusing on interpretability, robustness, and verification. Students study verification methods for neural networks, adversarial attacks and defenses, causal reasoning, and techniques for explaining model decisions. Emphasis is placed on practical methods that ensure AI systems behave reliably, especially in safety-critical areas like healthcare and autonomous driving.

professor: David McAllester, Toyota Technological Institute, Chicago
description: David McAllester's course offers a mathematically rigorous but accessible foundation for deep learning. Key topics include optimization (SGD, Adam), generalization theory, architectures (CNNs, RNNs, Transformers), and unsupervised learning. The lectures often bridge classical statistical learning theory with modern deep neural networks, giving students a principled understanding of why and how deep models work.

professor: Soheil Feize, University of Maryland, College Park
description: This course dives into theoretical and practical foundations behind modern deep learning. Topics include optimization landscapes, overparameterization, adversarial robustness, generalization bounds, and deep generative models. Through lectures and assignments, students explore not only how deep learning models succeed but also where they fail, and why certain architectures generalize better than others.

Andreas Geiger’s course provides a structured introduction to deep learning fundamentals and applications. It covers feedforward networks, CNNs, RNNs, and GANs, but also emphasizes modern approaches in computer vision like object detection and segmentation. It is particularly relevant for students interested in 3D vision and autonomous driving applications, given Geiger’s background (KITTI dataset creator).

This course offers a clear and comprehensive introduction to deep learning, especially focusing on practical engineering applications. The lectures systematically build from simple perceptrons to deep CNNs, GANs, and reinforcement learning, including application areas like medical imaging. Emphasis is given to understanding the math intuitively and coding deep learning models from scratch.

professor: Terence Parr and Yannet Interian, University of San Francisco
description: This course is a beginner-friendly yet thorough introduction to building deep learning models, particularly using PyTorch. Students cover topics like linear regression, feedforward neural networks, CNNs, and recurrent networks. The instructors emphasize project-based learning, culminating in a final project where students build and train complex deep learning pipelines.

professor: Pieter Abbeel, Sergey Karayev, UC Berkeley
description: This unique course focuses not just on designing models but on taking deep learning models from prototype to production. Topics include data management, model deployment, hardware acceleration, monitoring model drift, and scalability. Real-world case studies prepare students for building deployable AI systems in industry settings.

course: Deep Learning: Designing, Visualizing, and Understanding DNNs
description: Sergey Levine’s course teaches how deep networks work internally, beyond just training them. Topics include optimization visualization, loss surface analysis, robustness, generalization, and interpretability methods. Students are trained to not just apply deep learning but to critically evaluate and improve model behavior.

course: Deep Learning in the Life Sciences
description: This advanced interdisciplinary course explores how deep learning revolutionizes life sciences, genomics, and biomedical research. Topics include generative models for molecules, structure prediction, multi-omics analysis, and health AI. Students learn to apply deep learning creatively to biological data.

course: Introduction to Deep Learning and Generative Models
description: This course teaches the fundamentals of deep learning with an additional focus on generative models like VAEs and GANs. Students get practical experience building deep networks in PyTorch, learning techniques for model evaluation and transfer learning.

professor: Alfredo Canziani and Yann LeCun, NYU
description: This course provides a rich and intuitive understanding of deep learning, starting from basics and moving into convolutional networks, sequence modeling, energy-based models, and reinforcement learning. Taught by two renowned researchers, the course balances theory with many practical exercises and projects.

Focusing on real-world applications, this course walks students through building deep models for practical tasks such as image classification, natural language processing, and audio signal processing. It emphasizes experimentation with modern architectures like ResNet and transformers.

Hung-yi Lee’s famous lectures offer an intuitive yet technically solid approach to machine learning. The course covers traditional ML topics (SVMs, decision trees) and deep learning, and is well-known for its clear explanations and hands-on approach, available freely online with subtitles.

This series tackles the mathematical foundations underpinning deep learning, including optimization theory, information theory, linear algebra, and statistics. It's an ideal complement for students wanting to strengthen their theoretical rigor alongside practicing deep learning.

professor: Peter Bloem, Michael Cochez, and Jakub Tomczak, VU-Amsterdam
description: This course provides a strong foundation in modern deep learning, covering architectures, training procedures, optimization algorithms, and unsupervised learning methods. Projects involve practical application of techniques in real datasets and research contexts.

This course focuses on applying deep learning to scientific problems and engineering contexts. It covers regression, classification, sequence modeling, and scientific machine learning, with strong mathematical foundations and coding projects.

course: An Introduction to Group Equivariant Deep Learning
professor: Erik J. Bekkers, Universiteit van Amsterdam
description: This specialized course covers group-equivariant networks, an advanced topic focusing on how symmetry groups (like rotations, reflections) can be incorporated into neural networks to enhance generalization and data efficiency.

The gold standard of linear algebra lectures, Strang’s series teaches everything from matrix theory to vector spaces with clear geometric intuition. Widely beloved for how it makes mathematical foundations accessible to engineers and scientists.
This course is a primer on probability theory, emphasizing intuition and calculation. Topics include probability distributions, Bayes' theorem, expectation, variance, and common statistical models.

course: Information Theory, Pattern Recognition, and Neural Networks
description: This legendary lecture series covers the fundamentals of information theory, probabilistic modeling, and the theoretical basis for neural networks. Mackay’s explanations connect core principles across fields like compression, learning, and inference.

A concise and practical review of linear algebra aimed at machine learning practitioners. The course covers essential topics such as matrix multiplication, eigenvalues, and least-squares, with an emphasis on application.
A free YouTube series that explains probability distributions, random variables, hypothesis testing, and basic statistical inference in a highly accessible and practical way, aimed at undergraduates.
This lecture series offers an in-depth mathematical exploration of linear algebra, from fundamental concepts to more advanced topics like canonical forms. Highly visual and intuitive, yet rigorous.

An intuitive introduction to multivariable calculus topics such as partial derivatives, multiple integrals, and vector calculus, delivered with the clarity and visual style Grant Sanderson is famous for.

This beautifully visualized series breaks down the core ideas of linear algebra into intuitive concepts. Topics such as vector spaces, matrices, eigenvectors, and transformations are presented in a way that emphasizes geometric intuition over rote memorization. It's ideal for both beginners and those wanting to deeply understand the "why" behind linear algebra operations.

Grant Sanderson reimagines calculus not as a collection of formulas, but as a way of thinking about change and accumulation. The series covers derivatives, integrals, multivariable calculus, and Taylor series through dynamic visualizations, offering an intuitive foundation perfect for both students new to calculus and those wanting to strengthen their conceptual understanding.

This course provides the essential mathematical tools required for machine learning, covering probability, linear algebra, calculus, and optimization. Geoff Gordon explains concepts in an accessible manner, making it particularly valuable for students transitioning into machine learning from non-mathematical backgrounds.

course: Mathematics for Machine Learning (Linear Algebra, Calculus)
professor: David Dye, Samuel Cooper, and Freddie Page, IC-London
description: Accompanying a popular textbook, this course offers a structured and accessible introduction to the mathematics needed for modern machine learning. It starts with linear algebra and calculus fundamentals, gradually connecting them to practical ML applications like optimization and dimensionality reduction.

professor: S.K. Gupta and Sanjeev Kumar, IIT-Roorkee
description: This Indian Institute of Technology course covers multivariable calculus with mathematical rigor, including topics like partial derivatives, multiple integrals, vector calculus, and applications in physics and engineering. It serves as a solid mathematical foundation for machine learning and engineering studies.

This course introduces probability theory from an engineering perspective, covering topics like random variables, joint distributions, expectation, and Markov chains. It emphasizes solving real-world engineering problems through probabilistic modeling and intuition.

course: Matrix Methods in Data Analysis, Signal Processing, and Machine Learning
description: Gilbert Strang presents an elegant and practical exploration of matrices in the context of data science and signal processing. Topics include principal component analysis (PCA), least squares, and SVD (Singular Value Decomposition), linking linear algebra theory directly to modern applications.

This course delves into fundamental topics in information theory, such as entropy, mutual information, source coding, and channel capacity. It connects theoretical foundations to practical applications like data compression and communication systems.

A short intensive review course designed to prepare economics and social science students for graduate-level quantitative courses. Topics include calculus, linear algebra, probability, and optimization, taught with a focus on applications in economics and data science.

An updated and refined lecture series by Gilbert Strang emphasizing the modern role of linear algebra in machine learning, scientific computing, and data analysis. It covers familiar topics from 18.06 but with a stronger emphasis on numerical methods and applications.

course: Mathematics for Numerical Computing and Machine Learning
description: This course bridges numerical linear algebra, optimization, and machine learning. Topics include solving large systems of equations, eigenvalue problems, and the mathematical foundations behind training machine learning models.

Tailored for neuroscience researchers, this course teaches statistical inference, hypothesis testing, and Bayesian methods with applications to experimental neuroscience. It blends statistical rigor with practical data analysis challenges in biology.

professor: Ulrike von Luxburg, Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen
description: This mathematically rigorous course covers linear algebra, probability theory, and optimization specifically from a machine learning perspective. It’s ideal for students aiming to understand ML theory rather than just apply prebuilt models.

An excellent primer on causal inference methods, covering graphical models, potential outcomes, interventions, and counterfactuals. The course offers both theoretical understanding and practical modeling skills for drawing causal conclusions from data.

This course dives into linear algebra applications in engineering, focusing on matrix decompositions, least squares problems, and data science applications. It emphasizes computational techniques and hands-on problem-solving.

This course provides a comprehensive mathematical foundation for data science. Topics include linear models, optimization, probability theory, and basic statistics, all taught with a strong link to practical data science tasks.

course: Mathematics for Numerical Computing and Machine Learning
description: Building on earlier versions, Ryan Adams emphasizes solving linear systems, eigenproblems, and optimization challenges critical for scalable machine learning. Applications to deep learning and high-dimensional statistics are discussed.

A classic and deeply influential course, this series teaches the theory and applications of convex optimization, including interior-point methods, duality, and convex analysis. Boyd's intuitive explanations make advanced material highly accessible.

This Technion course covers classical optimization methods with a focus on algorithms like gradient descent, Newton's method, and constrained optimization. It balances theoretical proofs with numerical examples.

professor: S V N Vishwanathan, Purdue University
description: Focusing specifically on optimization challenges arising in ML, this course covers stochastic gradient methods, convex and non-convex optimization, and dual formulations. It is ideal for students who want a solid mathematical grasp of ML optimization.

An in-depth, graduate-level course that covers convex and non-convex optimization, focusing on real-world ML and statistical learning problems. Topics include subgradient methods, mirror descent, and Lagrangian duality.

A structured and theoretical course covering convex sets, convex functions, and optimization problems. It's especially valuable for students preparing for theoretical research or advanced machine learning applications.
This course covers both classical and modern optimization methods, building up from fundamental ideas to more advanced topics like variational inequalities and optimality conditions.

This course explores the theoretical and algorithmic foundations of ML, including learnability, generalization, and optimization under computational constraints. Ideal for students interested in the intersection of theoretical CS and ML.

A comprehensive course covering numerical methods for optimization including line search, trust region methods, and constrained optimization. It emphasizes practical algorithms for solving optimization problems arising in data science and engineering.

Ryan Tibshirani's lectures provide an accessible yet rigorous introduction to convex optimization, covering duality theory, optimality conditions, convex analysis, and applications in machine learning and statistics. Students learn how to recognize and exploit convex structure, with many real-world examples illustrating optimization in action.

This course presents a deep dive into advanced algorithmic techniques, including approximation algorithms, linear programming, spectral graph theory, and semidefinite programming. It focuses on algorithm design principles and complexity analysis for challenging computational problems.

Michael Zibulevsky teaches fundamental optimization methods with a focus on unconstrained and constrained optimization problems. Topics include gradient-based methods, Newton’s method, and KKT conditions, bridging theory with algorithmic implementations.

This version of 10-725 brings together two experts who jointly cover the theory and applications of convex optimization. Topics include first-order methods, strong duality, convex conjugates, and practical optimization frameworks widely used in machine learning.

A refreshed version of Tibshirani’s popular course that emphasizes practical algorithms like projected gradient descent, proximal methods, ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers), and applications in high-dimensional statistics and ML pipelines.

Taught by one of the founding fathers of modern convex optimization, this course covers first-order methods, accelerated gradient methods, and complexity theory. Nesterov’s lectures highlight both the mathematical beauty and practical power of optimization techniques.

An accessible crash course on optimization foundations tailored for economics and data science students. Covers convexity, optimality conditions, duality, and introduces linear and nonlinear programming.

professor: Michel Bierlaire, École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL)
description: This EPFL course offers a systematic study of optimization algorithms, including unconstrained and constrained problems, interior-point methods, and duality. It is geared toward engineering and operations research students.

professor: Michel Bierlaire, École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL)
description: Focusing on combining optimization with simulation techniques, this course addresses stochastic optimization, Monte Carlo methods, and how to solve complex problems under uncertainty. Applications span logistics, traffic networks, and finance.

professor: Lots of Legends, Instituto Nacional de Matemática Pura e Aplicada, Rio de Janeiro
description: A high-level research workshop featuring talks by world-leading optimization experts, covering topics from gradient methods to variational analysis and applications in continuous domains.

An ongoing international seminar series featuring frontier research talks on optimization theory, convex and non-convex methods, and machine learning applications. It showcases a diverse set of speakers from academia and industry.

A continuation of convex optimization topics focusing on stochastic optimization, robust optimization, and cutting-edge applications to machine learning. Emphasizes advanced duality theory and optimization under uncertainty.

An introduction to optimization over discrete structures, covering problems like matching, flows, integer programming, and approximation algorithms. The course balances combinatorial techniques with LP relaxations and real-world applications.

course: Optimization Methods for Machine Learning and Engineering
professor: Julius Pfrommer, Jürgen Beyerer, Karlsruher Institut für Technologie (KIT)
description: This course introduces students to optimization algorithms used in machine learning and engineering problems, including convex optimization, non-convex methods, and gradient-based optimization, with a focus on practical implementation and engineering intuition.

The legendary introductory course that has trained generations of machine learning practitioners. Covers supervised learning, unsupervised learning, support vector machines, and neural networks. Balances theory with coding assignments.

An intuitive and accessible course covering the foundations of supervised learning, Bayesian methods, decision trees, and boosting. Emphasizes conceptual understanding over heavy formalism, making it beginner-friendly.

One of the first formal machine learning courses ever taught, Mitchell’s lectures introduce key ML concepts such as overfitting, bias-variance tradeoff, Bayesian networks, and reinforcement learning. His book complements the course.

professor: Nando de Freitas, University of British Columbia
description: This course covers core machine learning methods and data mining techniques. Topics include SVMs, graphical models, PCA, and unsupervised learning. Known for its comprehensive coverage and accessible teaching style.

A brilliantly structured course that teaches machine learning foundations through a statistical learning theory lens. Topics include the VC dimension, overfitting, regularization, and generalization theory, balanced with practical intuition.

A classical approach to machine learning covering probabilistic modeling, kernel methods, and graphical models, aimed at engineering students. Focuses on real-world applications in robotics and autonomous systems.

This course covers fundamental ML algorithms, kernel methods, and optimization in machine learning. Alex Smola’s teaching connects core ideas to practical algorithms used in SVMs, structured prediction, and beyond.

professor: Alex Smola and Geoffrey Gordon, CMU
description: An extension of the 10-701 course with a stronger emphasis on scalable learning, Bayesian methods, and real-world applications in large-scale settings. Well-suited for students wanting an introduction with a strong theoretical backbone.

professor: Sukhendu Das, IIT-M and C.A. Murthy, ISI-Calcutta
description: A thorough exploration of statistical pattern recognition, including Bayesian classification, decision theory, clustering, and feature extraction. The course prepares students for practical applications in image and speech recognition.

course: An Introduction to Statistical Learning with Applications in R
professor: Trevor Hastie and Robert Tibshirani, Stanford
description: An applied machine learning course focused on statistical approaches such as regression, classification, and clustering. Accompanied by the widely praised book "An Introduction to Statistical Learning," it teaches ML through hands-on R programming.

This beginner-friendly Udacity course introduces core machine learning concepts including supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and model evaluation. Using intuitive explanations and simple Python code examples, it walks students through algorithms like decision trees, naive Bayes, SVMs, and k-means clustering. It’s an excellent choice for absolute beginners in ML.

A more technical introduction to machine learning, covering foundational models like linear regression, logistic regression, SVMs, boosting, and basic clustering. Dhruv Batra emphasizes understanding the math behind algorithms and their practical deployment, making it ideal for engineering students.

This course focuses on statistical approaches to classification, covering methods like kNN, logistic regression, discriminant analysis, and SVMs. Ali Ghodsi provides intuitive explanations with a strong emphasis on the mathematical properties of classifiers and their real-world behavior.

This course takes a deep dive into the theoretical foundations of machine learning, covering PAC learning, VC dimension, bias-variance decomposition, and generalization theory. It’s ideal for students who want a rigorous understanding of the "why" behind machine learning algorithms.

Alex Smola’s 10-701 series covers a wide array of machine learning topics, from linear models and SVMs to probabilistic graphical models and kernel methods. The course balances mathematical rigor with an emphasis on algorithmic design and real-world applications.

Larry Wasserman, a statistician’s statistician, teaches machine learning from a deep statistical perspective. Topics include regression, classification, density estimation, and clustering, with a strong focus on the theoretical guarantees behind algorithms.

professor: Michael Littman, Charles Isbell, Pushkar Kolhe, GaTech
description: This course offers a clear, engaging introduction to supervised learning concepts. Students explore decision trees, ensembles, and Bayesian learning through intuitive explanations and practical projects, making it accessible for those new to the field.

professor: Michael Littman, Charles Isbell, Pushkar Kolhe, GaTech
description: Complementing the supervised learning course, this series covers clustering, dimensionality reduction, and anomaly detection. It explains k-means, hierarchical clustering, PCA, and mixture models, emphasizing intuition and practical coding exercises.

An advanced CMU course that explores non-parametric methods, graphical models, structured prediction, and deep learning. It’s mathematically rigorous and best suited for students preparing for research or advanced machine learning applications.

Pedro Domingos offers a broad survey of machine learning methods, ranging from decision trees and Bayesian learning to ensemble methods and deep learning. His focus is on practical application and understanding the strengths and weaknesses of different algorithms.

An updated version of his earlier course, Wasserman continues his focus on rigorous statistical methods for learning, with expanded content on model selection, regularization techniques, and theory behind high-dimensional inference.

This course specializes in scaling machine learning algorithms to very large datasets. Topics include distributed learning, online learning, approximate inference, and scalable versions of classical models like linear regression and clustering.

A short course designed to provide essential math background for ML, covering linear algebra, probability, and basic optimization. Focused and efficient, it's aimed at getting students "math-ready" for more technical machine learning courses.

An updated and extended version of Ghodsi’s 2015 course, with additional topics such as ensemble methods (bagging, boosting) and neural network-based classifiers. Strong emphasis on performance evaluation and practical insights.

One of the most popular online courses globally, Andrew Ng’s ML course covers supervised learning, unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and advice for applying ML. Balanced between theory and intuition, it remains a gold standard for ML education.

This CMU introductory course emphasizes practical algorithmic understanding, covering supervised learning, unsupervised learning, evaluation metrics, and model selection. Focused on breadth and real-world relevance rather than heavy theory.

An advanced course focusing on statistical theory behind ML. Topics include concentration inequalities, empirical risk minimization, sparsity, and kernel methods, with heavy emphasis on proofs and understanding learning guarantees.

A specialized course applying machine learning techniques to computer vision problems such as image segmentation, recognition, and object detection. Emphasizes structured prediction models and graphical models for vision tasks.

An expanded, two-part version of Gordon’s earlier course, covering deeper topics in probability theory, matrix calculus, and optimization necessary for advanced machine learning and deep learning models.

This course covers modern techniques for visualizing high-dimensional data, including PCA, t-SNE, and manifold learning. Ali Ghodsi explains both the theory and practical considerations for making data visually interpretable.

Targeted at physicists, this course introduces machine learning concepts like supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and deep learning with applications to problems in quantum systems, materials science, and physics simulations.

This course teaches the core principles of building intelligent systems using machine learning. Topics include regression, classification, boosting, and deep learning, with a practical and project-driven focus.

professor: Tomaso Poggio, Lorenzo Rosasco, Sasha Rakhlin
description: An advanced course exploring the theoretical foundations of statistical learning, including generalization, empirical risk minimization, and the theory of deep learning. Ideal for students interested in ML research.

professor: Mike Gelbart, University of British Columbia
description: A comprehensive introduction to machine learning and data mining techniques, covering decision trees, ensemble methods, clustering, and deep learning. Emphasizes practical applications, programming, and model evaluation.

David Rosenberg teaches core machine learning concepts with an emphasis on mathematical foundations. Covers topics such as convex risk minimization, model complexity, regularization, and kernel methods, with practical coding assignments.

Andreas Krause offers a mathematically rigorous yet approachable introduction to machine learning. The course covers supervised learning, unsupervised learning, probabilistic models, and reinforcement learning. Emphasis is placed on algorithmic thinking, theoretical guarantees, and practical application, preparing students for both academic and industry settings.

This course delivers a clear and insightful introduction to machine learning, focusing on the statistical foundations of learning theory. Topics include classification, regression, bias-variance tradeoff, and clustering. Dasgupta’s explanations are intuitive yet mathematically grounded, making it ideal for both beginners and advanced students.

This graduate-level course covers machine learning fundamentals with a strong focus on probabilistic modeling, latent variables, and decision theory. Students explore classical algorithms like SVMs and boosting, as well as Bayesian approaches to learning. It’s particularly strong on interpretability and structured prediction.

Andrew Ng's legendary CS229 course remains a cornerstone for machine learning education. The course systematically covers supervised learning, unsupervised learning, generative learning algorithms, and advice for practical ML system design. It blends strong mathematical foundations with real-world intuition.

This course introduces core concepts from artificial intelligence and machine learning, with emphasis on understanding and designing intelligent agents. Topics include search algorithms, decision making under uncertainty, and learning from data, with applications in automation and robotics.

Pascal Poupart’s course covers the basics of machine learning, including regression, classification, clustering, and structured prediction. Strong emphasis is placed on probabilistic modeling, graphical models, and decision theory. The course balances theory with hands-on assignments.

A research-focused course that covers structured prediction, online learning, ranking, and learning to search. Thorsten Joachims emphasizes connections between machine learning theory and algorithm design, with strong practical and theoretical components.

This course covers advanced methods for handling structured prediction problems such as sequences, trees, and graphs. Topics include CRFs, structured SVMs, and approximate inference, with strong emphasis on applications in NLP and vision.

This ETH Zürich course dives into advanced machine learning topics like probabilistic graphical models, structured prediction, and deep generative models. Emphasizes formal mathematical frameworks and real-world application scenarios.
A specialized course focusing on the intersection of signal processing and machine learning. Topics include sparse coding, dictionary learning, and deep learning for audio and sensor signals.

A strong theoretical course covering supervised learning, unsupervised learning, generalization theory, and optimization. Animashree Anandkumar provides deep insights into tensor methods, latent variable models, and non-convex optimization landscapes.

Tailored for physicists, this course explains supervised and unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and deep learning in the context of physical systems. Covers how ML can assist in understanding quantum mechanics, materials, and dynamical systems.

Taught by one of the maintainers of scikit-learn, this hands-on course focuses on practical aspects of machine learning. Students learn data preprocessing, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and how to build and evaluate ML pipelines.

course: Fundamentals of Machine Learning over Networks
description: Focuses on decentralized and distributed machine learning over networks. Topics include federated learning, consensus algorithms, and communication-efficient ML methods, critical for modern large-scale ML deployments.

course: Foundations of Machine Learning and Statistical Inference
description: An expanded version of Anandkumar's 2019 course, adding emphasis on statistical inference topics, including hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and robust learning under uncertainty.

professor: Rebecca Willett and Yuxin Chen, University of Chicago
description: This course blends statistical rigor with modern ML techniques. Topics include high-dimensional statistics, optimization, generalization theory, and kernel methods, making it ideal for students wanting a strong mathematical grounding.

professor: Sanjay Lall and Stephen Boyd, Stanford University
description: An accessible introduction to machine learning, covering regression, classification, clustering, and dimensionality reduction. Focuses on practical algorithm design and data-driven problem solving with a mathematical underpinning.

Taught by one of the core developers of scikit-learn, this course provides a practical, hands-on approach to machine learning. It focuses on real-world application rather than theoretical derivations, covering data preprocessing, model building, hyperparameter tuning, model evaluation, and deployment considerations. Students learn a wide array of techniques, from classical algorithms like linear regression and decision trees to more advanced ensemble methods and basic deep learning.

professor: Ulrike von Luxburg, Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen
description: This course focuses on the statistical foundations of machine learning, including empirical risk minimization, VC dimension, concentration inequalities, and statistical guarantees for ML algorithm

professor: Philipp Hennig, Eberhard Karls Universität Tübingen
description: Covers Bayesian methods, probabilistic inference, and Gaussian processes in depth. Emphasizes probabilistic reasoning for modeling uncertainty in machine learning systems.
Comprehensive introduction to deep learning and classical machine learning methods. Covers CNNs, RNNs, generative models, and recent advances in self-supervised and reinforcement learning.
A rigorous course on machine learning fundamentals, covering supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and an introduction to geometric deep learning and group equivariant methods.

professor: Shayan Srinivasa Garani, Indian Institute of Science
description: Focuses on using neural networks for classical signal processing tasks, including filtering, denoising, and time-series analysis, bridging deep learning with traditional DSP techniques.
An approachable introduction to machine learning covering basic supervised and unsupervised learning methods, model evaluation, and overfitting, with intuitive explanations and real-world examples.

professor: Erik J. Bekkers, Universiteit van Amsterdam
description: Based on Bishop's Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning, this course provides a deep dive into probabilistic modeling, Bayesian inference, and statistical learning theory.

professor: Julien Mairal and Jean-Philippe Vert, Inria/ENS Paris-Saclay, Google
description: Focuses on kernel methods including SVMs, kernel ridge regression, and recent advances like scalable kernel approximations. Bridges classical statistical learning with modern scalable algorithms.
Introduces the field of continual (lifelong) learning, covering challenges like catastrophic forgetting and methods such as replay strategies, dynamic architectures, and meta-learning.

An advanced course introducing graphical models, potential outcomes, interventions, and counterfactuals. Emphasis is placed on learning causal structures from data and distinguishing causation from mere correlation.
